name: NgForm
comment: The form directive listens on submission requests and, depending, on if an action is set, the form will automatically either allow or prevent the default browser submission from occurring.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment: Returns true if there is no key-value pair in the map.

isNotEmpty.name: isNotEmpty
isNotEmpty.comment: Returns true if there is at least one key-value pair in the map.

values.name: values
values.comment:
The values of this.

The values are iterated in the order of their corresponding keys. This means that iterating angular.NgForm.keys and angular.NgForm.values in parrallel will provided matching pairs of keys and values.

The returned iterable has an efficient length method based on the angular.NgForm.length of the map.

keys.name: keys
keys.comment:
The keys of this.

The returned iterable has efficient length and contains operations, based on angular.NgForm.length and angular.NgForm.containsKey of the map.

The order of iteration is defined by the individual Map implementation, but must be consistent between changes to the map.

length.name: length
length.comment: The number of key-value pairs in the map.

constructors.comment:
Instantiates a new instance of NgForm. Upon creation, the instance of the class will be bound to the formName property on the scope (where formName refers to the name value acquired from the name attribute present on the form DOM element).

  • angular.NgForm.NgForm-.scope - The scope to bind the form instance to.
  • angular.NgForm.NgForm-.element - The form DOM element.
  • angular.NgForm.NgForm-.injector - An instance of Injector.

[]=.comment:
Associates the angular.NgForm.[]=.key with the given angular.NgForm.[]=.value.

If the key was already in the map, its associated value is changed. Otherwise the key-value pair is added to the map.

[].comment: Returns the value for the given key or null if key is not in the map. Because null values are supported, one should either use angular.NgForm.containsKey to distinguish between an absent key and a null value, or use the angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent method.

clear.name: clear
clear.comment:
Removes all pairs from the map.

After this, the map is empty.

remove.name: remove
remove.comment: Removes the association for the given key. Returns the value for key in the map or null if key is not in the map. Note that values can be null and a returned null value does not always imply that the key is absent.

containsKey.name: containsKey
containsKey.comment: Returns true if this map contains the given key.

containsValue.name: containsValue
containsValue.comment: Returns true if this map contains the given value.

addAll.name: addAll
addAll.comment:
Adds all key-value pairs of other to this map.

If a key of other is already in this map, its value is overwritten.

The operation is equivalent to doing this[key] = value for each key and associated value in other. It iterates over other, which must therefore not change during the iteration.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Applies f to each {key, value} pair of the map.

Adding or removing keys from the map during iteration is not allowed.

putIfAbsent.name: putIfAbsent
putIfAbsent.comment:
If key is not associated to a value, calls ifAbsent and updates the map by mapping key to the value returned by ifAbsent. Returns the value in the map.

Map<String, int> scores = {'Bob': 36};
for (var key in ['Bob', 'Rohan', 'Sophena']) {
  scores.putIfAbsent(key, () => key.length);
}
scores['Bob'];      // 36
scores['Rohan'];    //  5
scores['Sophena'];  //  7

The code that ifAbsent executes must not add or remove keys.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides angular.NgForm.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

keys.name: keys
keys.comment:
The keys of this.

The returned iterable has efficient length and contains operations, based on angular.NgForm.length and angular.NgForm.containsKey of the map.

The order of iteration is defined by the individual Map implementation, but must be consistent between changes to the map.

values.name: values
values.comment:
The values of this.

The values are iterated in the order of their corresponding keys. This means that iterating angular.NgForm.keys and angular.NgForm.values in parrallel will provided matching pairs of keys and values.

The returned iterable has an efficient length method based on the angular.NgForm.length of the map.

length.name: length
length.comment: The number of key-value pairs in the map.

isEmpty.name: isEmpty
isEmpty.comment: Returns true if there is no key-value pair in the map.

isNotEmpty.name: isNotEmpty
isNotEmpty.comment: Returns true if there is at least one key-value pair in the map.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and angular.NgForm.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the angular.NgForm.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

[].comment: Returns the value for the given angular.NgForm.[].key or null if angular.NgForm.[].key is not in the map. Because null values are supported, one should either use angular.NgForm.containsKey to distinguish between an absent key and a null value, or use the angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent method.

[]=.comment:
Associates the angular.NgForm.[]=.key with the given angular.NgForm.[]=.value.

If the key was already in the map, its associated value is changed. Otherwise the key-value pair is added to the map.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
angular.NgForm.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to angular.NgForm.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If angular.NgForm.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of angular.NgForm.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

addControl.name: addControl
addControl.comment:
Registers a form control into the form for validation.

  • angular.NgForm.addControl.control - The form control which will be registered (see ngControl).

removeControl.name: removeControl
removeControl.comment:
De-registers a form control from the list of controls associated with the form.

  • angular.NgForm.removeControl.control - The form control which will be de-registered (see ngControl).

updateControlValidity.name: updateControlValidity
updateControlValidity.comment:
Sets the validity status of the given control/errorType pair within the list of controls registered on the form. Depending on the validation state of the existing controls, this will either change valid to true or invalid to true depending on if all controls are valid or if one or more of them is invalid.

  • angular.NgForm.updateControlValidity.control - The registered control object (see ngControl).

  • angular.NgForm.updateControlValidity.errorType - The error associated with the control (e.g. required, url, number, etc...).

  • angular.NgForm.updateControlValidity.isValid - Whether the given error is valid or not (false would mean the error is real).

containsValue.name: containsValue
containsValue.comment: Returns true if this map contains the given value.

containsKey.name: containsKey
containsKey.comment: Returns true if this map contains the given key.

putIfAbsent.name: putIfAbsent
putIfAbsent.comment:
If angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent.key is not associated to a value, calls angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent.ifAbsent and updates the map by mapping angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent.key to the value returned by angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent.ifAbsent. Returns the value in the map.

Map<String, int> scores = {'Bob': 36};
for (var key in ['Bob', 'Rohan', 'Sophena']) {
  scores.putIfAbsent(key, () => key.length);
}
scores['Bob'];      // 36
scores['Rohan'];    //  5
scores['Sophena'];  //  7

The code that angular.NgForm.putIfAbsent.ifAbsent executes must not add or remove keys.

addAll.name: addAll
addAll.comment:
Adds all key-value pairs of angular.NgForm.addAll.other to this map.

If a key of angular.NgForm.addAll.other is already in this map, its value is overwritten.

The operation is equivalent to doing this[key] = value for each key and associated value in other. It iterates over angular.NgForm.addAll.other, which must therefore not change during the iteration.

remove.name: remove
remove.comment: Removes the association for the given angular.NgForm.remove.key. Returns the value for angular.NgForm.remove.key in the map or null if angular.NgForm.remove.key is not in the map. Note that values can be null and a returned null value does not always imply that the key is absent.

clear.name: clear
clear.comment:
Removes all pairs from the map.

After this, the map is empty.

forEach.name: forEach
forEach.comment:
Applies angular.NgForm.forEach.f to each {key, value} pair of the map.

Adding or removing keys from the map during iteration is not allowed.
